title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include business facilitation visitors, defined as aliens visiting the US temporarily for business purposes such as providing services or receiving training from a US entity. Admission as a business facilitation visitor is subject to certain conditions. Aliens visiting the US for business purposes must meet specific conditions, including being from a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security for anti-fraud measures and approval from a consular officer. Aliens visiting the US for business purposes must meet specific conditions, including being from a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security for anti-fraud measures and approval from a consular officer. The conditions for provision of services by the alien include all remuneration and expenses being paid by the employer, the alien being qualified with expert knowledge and necessary licenses. The conditions for provision or receipt of management or technical training by aliens in the US include being an employee of a firm affiliated with a US entity and having necessary licenses. The conditions for aliens to provide or receive management or technical training in the US include being affiliated with a US entity, having relevant experience, and having all expenses covered by their employer. Aliens seeking to provide management training must have at least 5 years of relevant experience and detailed knowledge of their employer's business operations. Those seeking to receive management training must hold a management level position within their employer within 1 year of completing the training. The period of authorized admission for business facilitation visitors providing professional services is limited to 1 year. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing professional services shall not exceed 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security under certain circumstances. The period of authorized admission for an alien admitted as a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training may not exceed 1 year. Business facilitation visitors are not eligible for a change of nonimmigrant status or adjustment to immigrant status during their stay in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission as business facilitation visitors if there is a pattern of fraud involving visa applications or other immigration matters. The Secretary may prohibit nationals from admission to the United States as business facilitation visitors if there is a pattern of fraud involving visa applications or other immigration matters. A qualifying services contract is defined as a contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a United States entity, outlining the time period, duties, remuneration, and working conditions for the alien. The qualifying services contract requires the foreign provider to pay the alien's remuneration and expenses, provide comparable working conditions, and ensure the alien has necessary credentials. The foreign provider is responsible for ensuring the alien's compliance with admission terms. The foreign provider is responsible for ensuring the alien's compliance with admission terms and their return to their home country at the end of their admission period.
